newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: INTERVIEW-Nat Mutual says shares weren't too cheap.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW-Nat Mutual says shares weren't too cheap.

text.p: National Mutual did not price its shares too cheaply before they were publicly floated, New Zealand general manager Anthony Ractliffe said on Tuesday.
His comments came shortly after National Mutual listed on the New Zealand and Australian stock exchanges at a sizeable premium to their retail and institutional application prices.
The shares listed in New Zealand at NZ$2.00 and traded up to $2.04, well above the retail application price of $1.70.
"I think it has certainly exceeded expectations, although we might have picked that there would be a premium when the institutions bid so well," Ractliffe told Reuters.
Brokers agreed that the initial share offering to both retail and institutional investors had been over-subscribed and demand for the stock was fierce at their listing.

But Ractliffe denied that the offer had been pitched too low. "At $1.70 the general comment at the time was that that was really at the high end of expectations," he said. "It was neatly pitched between net assets and net tangible assets."
Ractliffe said the listing had been aided by global equity market strength.
"We were helped in the end by generally good markets around the world, so I think we can be happy about that," he said. "But I think the whole pricing exercise has been excellent."
The listing marked the end of a "very successful episode for the company" and had paved the way for other companies to demutualise in National Mutual's wake.

"We're the first cab off the rank in this part of the world and I have no doubt that other companies will follow -- we know CML (Colonial Mutual Life) are following shortly and there's a lot of talk about AMP and to a lesser extent Tower," he said.
"Really, it boils down in the end to where you get your capital from in the future, and it is becoming increasingly difficult to raise capital as a mutual organisation.
"So I think they will follow our trend, but in fact, to be fair, we're only following an international trend."
While the listing heralds a new era for National Mutual, it also marks the end of a 30-year career for Ractliffe, who will leave the company in about a month.

"I feel I'm leaving the company on a high and I'm looking forward to doing something else around Wellington and still maintaining very friendly relationships, and indeed I'll be on a couple of National Mutual boards," he said.
National Mutual is owned 51 percent by insurance and financial services giant Axa SA.
There were four million shares traded in the hour's trading available on the New Zealand exchange. Brokers said there was strong demand.

"I think a lot of the institutions didn't get the holdings or the numbers that they were after, and I know that a lot of the retail investors were also scaled down. So I guess the natural progression on from there is that when they opened they were going to open at a bit of a premium, said Duncan Rutherford, broker at ANZ Securities.
